hobby.message: Freestyle FPV drones still keeping you sane?
Origami's still better than meds, huh?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: City’s what it is. Quiet enough, most days.
I keep busy fixing up old typewriters. Nothing complicated.
Had to do it in the dark when the power went funny last week.
Can’t complain. Still keeping to myself.
Restored another typewriter recently. Keeps me occupied.
Strange week, with the power cuts and all.
Makes small things like that… harder.
Still managed to get the ink ribbon in place.
The city gives what it gives. I find my routines.
Restoring antique typewriters—bit unusual, I know. Old habit.
Electricity outages last week made it slower than usual.
Forums for spare parts were down, so I improvised.
Ran it by lamplight all evening.
A bell’s ding means more than most news right now.
City’s quieter, but not always kinder these days.
I still spend hours on my old typewriter repairs.
Lost access to a few online manuals when the networks went out.
Had to take apart a Remington by lamplight. Felt almost like old times.
Strange satisfaction, that click when the carriage sets right.
Reminds me there’s order outside the system, too.
Small things survive, even when larger systems stutter.
Kind? City’s less interested in kindness lately. Stability, maybe.
I restore antique typewriters, write a little by hand. Used to be common enough.
Last week’s BCI hiccups knocked out my digital reference guides—should’ve seen the confusion.
Worked through a blackout on a Remington, guided by muscle memory instead of diagrams.
Always keep fresh ink ribbons hidden—old intelligence habits die hard.
Years ago, I watched these machines gather dust as the new systems grew.
Strange, but sometimes the failures bring back a sort of freedom.
For a few hours, the hum of oversight vanished. Only the typebars mattered.
hobby_answer: Still collecting. Just old keys and ribbons, nothing special now.
Kept one on my desk last week. Power failed mid-repair.
Didn’t use the network. Too much noise with the outages.
You have to adapt. That’s all.
Easier to keep things offline these days.
Yes, typewriters. Quiet hobby now.
Had to work by lamplight recently. Network was down in my building.
The system outages make online forums unreliable anyway.
Kept my projects simple. No need for notice.
Everything’s being watched, so I stay careful.
Manual repairs are safest these days.
Still restoring them, yes. Been at it for decades.
Lost access to my usual manuals last week—no network, thanks to this chaos.
Had to go by memory fixing a Remington, first time in years.
Strange how quiet the building got during the patrols.
Guess these old machines are more dependable than the system now.
Neighbors barely spoke all evening. Everyone distracted.
Still collecting, always. Brings some order to things.
Actually, with the BCI up and down, I had to work without internet.
Patrols outside made the halls tense. Got through it with candle and memory.
Suppose manuals can’t help if you can’t access them.
Kind of satisfying—no algorithms prompting you when it’s just ink and gears.
I kept logs by hand, as I did before all this.
Feels like a small rebellion. No risk of tampering.
Always. Only hobby that never lies back to you.
Used to check repair forums, trade ribbons quietly—now with the crackdowns, better to disappear.
BCI failures meant I worked alone, old school. Memory and candlelight.
Funny how power cuts push everyone into silence, no one trusting their own tech.
Kept handwritten logs as always—habit from days I still trusted my own judgement.
Saw some neighbors getting jittery, BCI score swings driving folks mad.
Reminds me of when the first pilots ran wild, whole blocks scrambling.
Feels safer to fix a carriage than talk these days. System never cared for hands-on work.
My Remington is older than Halden’s reforms, and lately, more reliable.
